issues.title: Add GitHub repo link in draft

issues.body: Add GitHub repo link in draft for easy issue filing

issues.title: Confidential Data Collaboration, specifically SMPC
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: This is not an ideal use case (certainly should not appear as the first one) because SMPC, when deployed correctly, should not be vulnerable to active attackers, i.e. it should provide "malicious security" and not just "semi honest security".

issues.title: High-Assurance Command Execution
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body:
The requirement is questionnable, because a malicious execution environment does not need a command to do its harm. It is actually the _operator_ that needs to be attested in this use case.

A similar consideration applies to "Securing Control and Management Planes" where again, the vulnerable point is the administrator. In that case, we mention stealing credentials as a risk, but it is significantly easier to address credential stealing (e.g. by using PAKE) than with attestation infrastructure.

issues.title: Use Cases vs. Properties
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: A general problem with this draft is that there is no connection between Sec. 3 and Sec. 4, to a level where they could each be a separate draft.

issues.title: Valid but Old
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body:
> attacks where an attacker presents valid, but old or unrelated Evidence from a different connection or context

I suggest dropping "old" because age of the Evidence is a criterion when evaluation it for validity.

issues.title: Binding to Machine Identifier
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body:
References to slides are frowned upon. Also, this is importnat enough to justify a few paragraphs of text here.

In addition, the short sentence here makes a ton of assumptions on the deployment model (e.g. "infrastructure provider") that require clarification.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body:
> References to slides are frowned upon.

Unfortunately, we could not manage to complete the pre-print for the formal analysis work until the cutoff. The link will be replaced by that in the future.

issues.title: Attestation Credential Freshness
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: RFC 9334 discusses freshness as related to periods of time. This section takes a rather extreme position that the Evidence needs to be bound to the specific connection. This may be very challenging in real life cases, e.g. many short-lived connections, or even many connections spawned in parallel. The requirement may be right for attested TLS, but needs a strong justification.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body: The pre-print (to be finalized this week) provides the formal reasoning behind this. We can add a reference to that.

issues.title: Negotiation and Capability Discovery: Fallback
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: In TLS, "graceful fallback" is the root of all evil. I suggest to drop it from the requirement or at least to clarify where fallback is acceptable and does not result in huge security issues.

comments.author: muhammad-usama-sardar
comments.body: Do you have a pointer to one concrete security issue?

issues.title: Negotiation and Capability Discovery: Formats
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: The "conceptual wrappers" are aimed at reducing the need for peers to understand RATS formats. This section should mention this fact, and perhaps the solution should allow for format negotiation that remains opaque to the endpoints.

issues.title: Privacy Preservation
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body:
The solution does not degrade the privacy -> The solution must not degrade the privacy (this is a requirement).

Also I suggest to to cite the [IAB Statement](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/statement-iab-statement-on-the-risks-of-attestation-of-software-and-hardware-on-the-open-internet/) in this section, it is not precisey about privacy but it is closely related.

issues.title: Security Considerations
issues.author: yaronf
issues.body: This section is confusing since it overlaps significantly with the requirements. I suggest to fold its text into the requirements section and use the stanard boilerplate: "This whole document is about security."

Thanks, it somehow worked as is [here](https://github.com/muhammad-usama-sardar/tls-fatt-extension/blob/main/draft-usama-tls-fatt-extension.md?plain=1). I just copied and pasted from there. Just for my knowledge, is there a difference of configuration that makes it work there?
It's not a matter of configuration; it's the context that matters.  You need to match the surrounding indentation pattern.

Can you expand on `provider`?  One option below.

```suggestion
## Cryptographic Binding to Platform Provider Identity

Evidence should be cryptographically bound to the platform provider identity to prevent diversion attacks {{Meeting-122-TLS-Slides}}.
```

I'm not convinced that's what you meant, though

It could be a cloud provider if VM is running on the cloud, or otherwise some other infrastructure provider.
Would 'infrastructure provider' be better? We can wordsmith it.
Sure, infrastructure provider is better, though is the entire phrase accurate? By which I mean, is it the "infrastructure provider identity" that is bound, or the "infrastructure identity"?

I understand the diversion being triggered by the lack of "unique machine identity”, regardless of who the identity provider is.

P.S.: Using the word “identity" tends to lead people down rabbit holes.
Then maybe `Cryptographic binding to unique machine identifier` is better?

How about "identifier of infrastructure provider"?

> I understand the diversion being triggered by the lack of "unique machine identity”, regardless of who the identity provider is.

I don't expect cloud providers to reveal unique machine identifiers. I think "identity provider" should be in the trust anchor store.

Hmm, that's fair.

Whether or not the machine identifier is revealed is irrelevant.  What matters is that a given machine can prove its identity to the credential provider and that this identity is used to create the binding credential.

You are in the rough :P

> > Whether or not the machine identifier is revealed is irrelevant. What matters is that a given machine can prove its identity to the credential provider and that this identity is used to create the binding credential.
>
> What does "identity" entail here?

The ability to single out a given machine (or a group of machines in an anonymity group).

> Also, that seems only applicable to the passport model.

Why?  Not at all.

I don’t think this should be about the “identifier of the infra provider”.
It should be about an “identifier provided to the machine by the infra provider”.

> Also, that seems only applicable to the passport model.

Must've forgotten the model before, but I think the whole flow was something like:

* New device gets added to a provider's estate.
* Provider issues a credential for the device (and potentially provisions cryptographic material to go with it too); the credential specifies who the provider is, where the device is located etc.
* Workload on the device tries to use aTLS, including binding to the device credential; you therefore need to somehow bind the session to this credential

If I understand correctly, we're all talking about this last step. Don't think it's passport model specifically, the device credential must've been issued before, but the background check/passport does not relate to this credential.
ok, that works for me.

We should make it clear that the diversion attack is deployment- and architecture-specific.

```suggestion
In certain deployments and for specific hardware architectures, diversion attacks are possible {{Meeting-122-TLS-Slides}}.
To prevent such an attack, Evidence should be cryptographically bound to the identifier provided to the machine by the infrastructure provider.
```
Makes sense, makes me wonder whether we should add qualifiers for the other properties too.
I don't disagree, but I don't have any specific suggestions except for this one right now.

> We should make it clear that the diversion attack is deployment- and architecture-specific.

I would like to see at least one concrete counterexample of an _existing_ deployment and/or hardware architecture where this attack is not applicable.
Arm CCA with per-machine instance ID?

There is no _existing_ deployment for Arm CCA yet, right? And that needs more discussion as in how that would identify that this machine is in a cloud provider's data center. Anyway, I propose we leave as it is, because it is one of the requirements that our protocol design needs to satisfy. This document -- at least the way I am thinking of it -- is just describing our requirements for protocol design and we agree that it is a requirement. Whether it is deployment-specific or hardware architecture-specific does not matter for this document in my view. 
If we really want to qualify it, we should thoroughly discuss how Arm CCA avoids this and then qualify other properties too.

> […] how that would identify that this machine is in a cloud provider's data center

We have already discussed this point: via an endorsement that binds the machine’s instance ID with the network/geographical location.

Stepping a bit back, we should have a clear separation between things that are strictly necessary regardless of the underlying technologies, and those that depend on how these technologies work, even if some conditions are not met in deployments right now. Don't think our intent should be to write specs only for what exists right now.

As an example, the cryptographic binding between RA and Secure Channel (SC) sessions should always be there one way or another, otherwise RA is useless. No change to platform / RA / TLS can be enough to overcome that.

> We have already discussed this point: via an endorsement that binds the machine’s instance ID with the network/geographical location.

I said _thorough_ discussions vs. top-of-head discussions.

- Who provides this Endorsement in the real world? Please point me to one concrete specification and one concrete deployment.
- Please name one concrete cloud provider that provides such machine’s instance ID in the Evidence. Without this, the Endorsement is useless.

> we should have a clear separation between things that are strictly necessary regardless of the underlying technologies, and those that depend on how these technologies work

My point is: it is not followed in the rest of the document. For example, "Performance and Efficiency" in the draft is also dependent on the underlying technology. Why are we emphasizing it here only?

The purpose is to list the requirements, and we agree that it is a requirement. Whether some technology fulfills it or not is not the aim of this document. Let's not make it a technology comparison document.

> My point is: it is not followed in the rest of the document. For example, "Performance and Efficiency" in the draft is also dependent on the underlying technology. Why are we emphasizing it here only?

Agree, and I was keen to follow this one up and make it uniform, it's just something that didn't occur to me the first time around. I'll open an issue to address in a future revision.

> The purpose is to list the requirements, and we agree that it is a requirement.

Agree here too, but as I pointed out above, there are also nuances that should be made clear _somewhere_ for people who want to deploy something.
